p.hi: Q: Do you remember being inspected there, by any chance?

div.p: EARDLEY: I don't think so. We were inspected I believe in Colombo.

p.hi: Q: I think it's time now to make that leap to Kigali.

div.p: EARDLEY: Oh, yes! Yes, indeed. . . . Were you afraid of my arrival in Kigali?

p.hi: Q: I don't recall being afraid of your arrival. Why?

div.p: EARDLEY: You seemed a little bit edgy.

p.hi: Q: Well, sure. You had come from working for all the top ambassadors in the hemisphere, and I was at the bottom. No, I don't think I was fearful, but I was fearful about embarrassing myself dictating and that sort of thing. Because I'd never dictated, not really.

div.p: EARDLEY: I'll never forget your remark on the telephone. In Eugene, Oregon. You said that you had looked at my personnel record, and I had worked for so many high-ranking, important ambassadors that you couldn't figure out why I'd be willing to come to Kigali. I don't remember whether I said, “Mr. Ambassador, because they won't give me a job.”

No, they really wanted desperately for me to resign, because they could have hired three secretaries for my salary. And I couldn't get a raise. I was at the top. Do you know, two weeks before I retired, I got the eighth step on a Three? They waited that long. Instead of giving me a Two. They could be nasty sometimes. I earned every bit of that.

p.hi: Q: Let's see, that was just as President Carter was getting started, after Gerald Ford.

div.p: EARDLEY: Seventy-seven. Well, fortunately for this girl, an old Africa hand stationed in Washington at that time saw what they were trying to do to me. They were shafting me. And she took me under her wing.

p.hi: Q: What was her name?

div.p: EARDLEY: Mary . . . . not Rosemary. Nice person. Young.

p.hi: Q: It wasn't Mary Ryan, was it?

div.p: EARDLEY: No. But she saved my life. Because the next time I got a telephone call from Washington, it said they had news for me. They had Kigali, Rwanda or Conakry. I said, I'll take Kigali. And there was utter silence. Couldn't believe it.

p.hi: Q: Why? Because it was so remote and unimportant?

div.p: EARDLEY: No, not many people wanted to go to either of those places. I did not want Conakry, so I chose the right one. And that's when she said, “That's interesting, because our ambassador to Rwanda happens to be in the department right now.” So they had you call me, after you had read my record. I don't know if you had all my record at that time. Did you have the Carl Sommerlatte stuff?

p.hi: Q: I don't think so.

div.p: EARDLEY: What a bitch he was!

p.hi: Q: Well, you could have worked for Bill Harrop in Conakry or Oliver Crosby.

div.p: EARDLEY: Well, I didn't need it.

p.hi: Q: Harrop was one of my great friends.

div.p: EARDLEY: Yeah, I liked Harrop, what little I know of him. I think I chose the right one. And then they threw in that TDY. It was one of the good points about being assigned to Rwanda because the TDY included Johannesburg, South Africa. I would never have got to South Africa otherwise, and I loved it.

p.hi: Q: That was before you arrived in Kigali.

div.p: EARDLEY: Yeah. And the principal officer there was Mac [William McKinley] Johnson. We had sort of parted Canada on not too friendly terms. He felt I had done him dirt when I was on the selection boards [about?] his secretary. I wasn't there. I was out on the beach with Ambassador Handley. And the other members of the selection board wrote that he had not written a very good, substantive report on Mary Keim. Do you know Mary Keim? She was very well known in our Foreign Service. A very good secretary.

p.hi: Q: Is that K-i-m-e?

div.p: EARDLEY: K-E-I-M, I think. And he took exception to that. But anyway, we cleared things up. I was there for six weeks. Loved it.

p.hi: Q: You got along well with him after you cleared the air?

div.p: EARDLEY: Oh, yes. He was a nice guy. Anyway, that's all about Johannesburg I can remember.

p.hi: Q: Then we go back to Kigali and the volleyball games, and the DCM.

div.p: EARDLEY: Well, I loved Kigali. That's one reason why I retired from there. I could leave with a very good taste in my mouth after 30 years in the Foreign Service. And that's the way to do it.

p.hi: Q: What did you enjoy about Kigali?

div.p: EARDLEY: The people.

p.hi: Q: The embassy people or the Rwandan people?

div.p: EARDLEY: Embassy people. Both. And especially the Tutsis.

p.hi: Q: You had Tutsi staff in your apartment?

div.p: EARDLEY: Yes. Our guard, our main guard, was a Tutsi. And I liked all the Tutsis in the embassy too.

p.hi: Q: Who was the administrative officer when you were there? Was that Rick Kramer or was that Joe Sikes?

div.p: EARDLEY: Rick Kramer. But I know Joe Sikes. How do I know him?

p.hi: Q: Well, he preceded Rick in Kigali.

div.p: EARDLEY: Was he there when I arrived?

p.hi: Q: I'm not sure.

div.p: EARDLEY: Oh yes, Kramer came after.

p.hi: Q: Now, did you travel outside Kigali? Did you get up to Dian Fossey's camp?

div.p: EARDLEY: No. I deliberately stayed away because I did not want to do anything to alienate her. And it could happen just so easily. She stayed at my apartment when she stopped staying at the ambassador's residence.

p.hi: Q: Why did she stop staying at the ambassador's residence?

div.p: EARDLEY: I think she found she was more comfortable in my funny little place. She would come down, she would be filthy dirty. Unkempt. She'd go in the bathroom and stay at least two hours, come out looking like a fashion model. I loved her. I think what happened to her is so tragic,

p.hi: Q: Did you get to know Rosamond Carr?

div.p: EARDLEY: Oh, sure, very well.

p.hi: Q: Did you ever visit her home?

div.p: EARDLEY: Oh, yes, many times.

p.hi: Q: She had such a pretty place.

div.p: EARDLEY: I ran across a picture of her place the other day and I couldn't believe my eyes. It was all overgrown with . . . I don't know what it was . . . ivy? All across the front.

p.hi: Q: How much did you have to do with government people?

div.p: EARDLEY: I'm afraid not enough.

p.hi: Q: The ambassador didn't have you making appointments for him?

div.p: EARDLEY: Yeah, calling on the other ambassadors.

p.hi: Q: Do you remember dealing with the Russians, for example?

div.p: EARDLEY: I can't remember Russians there.

p.hi: Q: You don't recall that they had a residence right behind our residence, separated by just a fence? We played volleyball a couple of times.

div.p: EARDLEY: Did they come over? I don't recall that.

p.hi: Q: Maybe that's my imagination.

div.p: EARDLEY: No . . .

p.hi: Q: Were there others in the diplomatic community that you were in touch with?

div.p: EARDLEY: I don't think we had a very active community, did we?

p.hi: Q: The diplomatic community as a whole, not very. The Germans were there, the Brits and the French were there, and of course the Belgians.

div.p: EARDLEY: Yeah. I wish the Belgians had managed to speak proper French. I couldn't understand them. And especially Ruth Median [Mrs. Eardley's predecessor as secretary].

p.hi: Q: When did you encounter Ruth?

div.p: EARDLEY: She was there when I arrived.

p.hi: Q: So there was some overlap?

div.p: EARDLEY: Yeah. I didn't appreciate it. I didn't need her.

p.hi: Q: Well, the nervous one about your coming was Ruth.

div.p: EARDLEY: Oh, really??

p.hi: Q: Sure. She knew that she was going to have a successor who was very accomplished.

div.p: EARDLEY: I'm sorry.

p.hi: Q: She was a very fine person. But she had something to worry about, because she was outranked!

div.p: EARDLEY: We had some good times, I'll tell you. I wouldn't give that up for anything.

p.hi: Q: Any more of those good times you want to recall here?

div.p: EARDLEY: Well, I spent quite a bit of time talking to other secretaries who were miserable. I said, “Look, you're guests in that country. Act like it. Learn the language. Get acquainted with them. And then you will reap the benefits.” I guess a lot of people thought I took it too seriously, but it was my life and my livelihood. And I loved it. Sometimes it was tough.

p.hi: Q: But you never got shot at?

div.p: EARDLEY: Oh, yes! In Chengmai. I also drove over a python in Chengmai.

p.hi: Q: I did that in Kinshasa too. It was the scariest thing! [Both laugh.] Well, do you have more to say about Kigali? Oh, you didn't talk about Ambassador Melone!

div.p: EARDLEY: I liked him. I thought he was a nice guy.

p.hi: Q: Was he a competent guy? Did he get along well with the Rwandans?

div.p: EARDLEY: Yes. And of course he was fluent in French. I liked Dominique [Mrs. Melone] also, except she did him wrong.

p.hi: Q: How so?

div.p: EARDLEY: She left him!

p.hi: Q: From Kigali?

div.p: EARDLEY: Well, she never did come to live there. I felt sorry for him.

p.hi: Q: I don't know how an ambassador could live there as a bachelor.

div.p: EARDLEY: Yeah, tough. But he had all of us, Judy Chidester [code clerk] — Also, Melone played bridge, and he enjoyed our company. You know, the swimming pool was at my apartment. He came over almost every day and swam.

p.hi: Q: Good for him! Did he have children who came to post?

div.p: EARDLEY: They had a daughter. I felt sorry for her too, because of this. Dominique just wanted to live in France, that's all.

p.hi: Q: Do you remember Martin Brennan?

div.p: EARDLEY: Ah, yes indeed. I liked him and I liked his wife Efron [sic, phon.] What was her name?

p.hi: Q: Her name was Giovanna.

div.p: EARDLEY: I called her Efron.

p.hi: Q: She didn't object?

div.p: EARDLEY: I didn't think so. I thought that was her name.

p.hi: Q: [joking] Maybe he changed wives after I left.

div.p: EARDLEY: No. But he did something that he shouldn't have. He took a picture, or several pictures, of her giving birth. And showed them to everyone. I don't think he should have done that. Well, it's all right for their own privacy but not to show around the embassy.

p.hi: Q: A little bit indiscreet.

div.p: EARDLEY: . . . .But I say, “Chacun � son go�t.” (Each to his own taste.) [laughs] I've pulled some awful things too, I guess.
[Mrs. Eardley passed away on June 4, 2008, at her home in Burlington, six weeks after this final interview session.]
End of interview
